title: Figsbury Ring Walking Route

images.title: Jim Champion, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Figsbury Ring 1

images.title: Trish Steel, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: The hill fort covers some 15.5 acres with original entrances to the east and west. The fort has a single rampart, up to 4m high. A ditch in the interior is clearly unfinished and may have provided material for the rampart.

images.title: Trish Steel, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Cattle at the site.

images.title: Stuart Buchan / Figsbury Ring car park
images.caption: This car park only allows access to Figsbury Ring. On the eastern boundary is MOD property. An MOD warning sign can just be seen in the photo.

images.title: Andrew Smith / Barracks, Winterbourne Gunner
images.caption: Defence CBRN Centre, Winterbourne Gunner near the Porton Down MOD land and viewed from the hillside below Figsbury Ring.

images.title: Trish Steel, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Dog on the rampart admiring the view.

description: This walk visits the Iron Age hill fort of Figsbury Ring near the city of Salisbury in Wiltshire. The remote site is located just a few miles north east of Salisbury . You can start your walk from the on site car park and then follow footpaths west up to the hill top. From here you can enjoy some glorious views over the countryside to Salisbury Plain and the city with its famous cathedral. It's particularly lovely in the warmer months when you can see butterflies and skylarks around the pretty wildflowers. The Monarch's Way crosses the hill. You could pick up this waymarked trail and follow it north west to visit the nearby villages of Winterbourne Dauntsey and Winterbourne Gunner. Head south east takes you across Winterbourne Down to Middle Winterslow.
